name: Id

types.name: Db
types.comment: A dictionary that uses `Id` as keys

types.name: Origin
types.comment:
Data that comes from a remote source usually has an id, while data that is made locally doesnt. If thats your situation, using this `Origin` type might be a better way of representing your datas id.

    type alias Car =
        { origin : Origin
        , make : String
        }

    saveCar : Car -> Http.Request (Result Err ())
    saveCar car =
        case car.origin of
            Id id ->
                Car.update id car

            New ->
                Car.create car

values.name: decoder
values.comment:
Decode an `Id`

    Decode.decodeString (Decode.field "id" Id.decoder) "{\"id\":\"19\"}"
    -- Ok (Id 19) : Result String Id

values.name: encode
values.comment:
Encode an `Id`

    Encode.encode 0 (Id.encode id)
    -- ""hDFL0Cs2EqWJ4jc3kMtOrKdEUTWh"" : String

    [ ("id", Id.encode id) ]
        |> Encode.object
        |> Encode.encode 0

    -- {\"id\":\"hDFL0Cs2EqWJ4jc3kMtOrKdEUTWh\"} : String

values.name: fromString
values.comment:
The only way to make an Id

    Id.fromString "vq93rUv0A4"

values.name: generator
get
values.comment: Get the item with a given id, if its in the `Db`

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a new item into a `Db`

values.name: items
values.comment: Get just the items in a `Db`

values.name: toDb
values.comment:
Make a `Db` that uses `Id` as keys

    type alias User =
        { id : Id
        , name : String
        }


    toDb .id users : Db User
